column1: #Text=Anne of Austria at the Age of Forty-six .
#Text=Touches upon the Strange Effects a Half-pistole may have .
#Text=D’Artagnan , Going to a Distance to discover Aramis .
#Text=10 . Monsieur Porthos du Vallon de Bracieux de Pierrefonds .
#Text=Duc de Beaufort amused his Leisure Hours in the Donjon of Vincennes .
#Text=Pates made by the Successor of Father Marteau are described .
#Text=One of the Forty Methods of Escape of the Duc de Beaufort .
#Text=The timely Arrival of D’Artagnan in Paris .
#Text=The four old Friends prepare to meet again .
#Text=How , sometimes , the Unhappy mistake Chance for Providence .
#Text=In which it is proved that first Impulses are oftentimes the best .
#Text=Te Deum for the Victory of Lens .
#Text=The Tower of St. Jacques de la Boucherie .
#Text=How D’Artagnan and Porthos earned by selling Straw .
#Text=In which we hear Tidings of Aramis .
#Text=Noble Natures never lose Courage , nor good Stomachs their Appetites .
#Text=How Mousqueton had a Narrow Escape of being eaten .
#Text=Thinking that Porthos will be at last a Baron , and D’Artagnan a Captain .
#Text=Shows how with Threat and Pen more is effected than by the Sword .
#Text=Difficult for Kings to return to the Capitals of their Kingdoms .

#Text=In a splendid chamber of the Palais Royal , formerly styled the Palais Cardinal , a man was sitting in deep reverie , his head supported on his hands , leaning over a gilt and inlaid table which was covered with letters and papers .

#Text=Behind this figure glowed a vast fireplace alive with leaping flames ; great logs of oak blazed and crackled on the polished brass andirons whose flicker shone upon the superb habiliments of the lonely tenant of the room , which was illumined grandly by twin candelabra rich with wax-lights .

#Text=Any one who happened at that moment to contemplate that red simar -- the gorgeous robe of office -- and the rich lace , or who gazed on that pale brow , bent in anxious meditation , might , in the solitude of that apartment , combined with the silence of the ante-chambers and the measured paces of the guards upon the landing-place , have fancied that the shade of Cardinal Richelieu lingered still in his accustomed haunt .
#Text=It was , alas ! the ghost of former greatness .

#Text=France enfeebled , the authority of her sovereign contemned , her nobles returning to their former turbulence and insolence , her enemies within her frontiers -- all proved the great Richelieu no longer in existence .

#Text=In truth , that the red simar which occupied the wonted place was his no longer , was still more strikingly obvious from the isolation which seemed , as we have observed , more appropriate to a phantom than a living creature -- from the corridors deserted by courtiers , and courts crowded with guards -- from that spirit of bitter ridicule , which , arising from the streets below , penetrated through the very casements of the room , which resounded with the murmurs of a whole city leagued against the minister ; as well as from the distant and incessant sounds of guns firing -- let off , happily , without other end or aim , except to show to the guards , the Swiss troops and the military who surrounded the Palais Royal , that the people were possessed of arms .
